Graphical abstract Ammonia decomposition is a promising route for CO2-free hydrogen production, but the development of efficient and cost-effective catalysts remains a challenge. Here, we employed a dual approach combining computational screening and free energy analysis to identify optimal catalysts, which were then validated experimentally. Pearson correlation coefficient analysis revealed a volcano-type relationship between NH3 dissociation energy (Ediss,NH3) and N2 adsorption energy (Ead,N2), highlighting Ru as the most effective monometallic catalyst. Reactor tests using supported Ru, Rh, Ir, Ni, and Co catalysts confirmed these predictions, with Ru exhibiting the highest NH3 conversion and a strong correlation between turnover frequency, activation energy (Ea), and electronic descriptors. Using this validated approach, we extended our analysis to bimetallic systems, identifying Ru-Ni alloys, as a promising alternative with balanced NH3 activation and N2 desorption. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of combining computational and experimental methods to design high-performance NH3 decomposition catalysts. Further refinement of Ru-Ni alloy synthesis and structural control could enhance catalytic activity, supporting scalable hydrogen production. Keywords Computational screening NH3 decomposition DFT Hydrogen production RuNi alloy catalysts Bimetallic catalysts Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3) has emerged as a promising hydrogen carrier due to its high hydrogen content (17.6 wt%), ease of liquefaction, and well-established storage and transport infrastructure. It offers a CO2-free and practical pathway for on-demand hydrogen production via catalytic decomposition (2NH3 → N2 + 3H2), making it a key enabler for hydrogen-based energy systems. However, efficient NH3 decomposition relies heavily on developing effective catalysts capable of facilitating the reaction with high activity and stability [1–5]. Among various catalysts, Ru is widely recognized as the most efficient for NH3 decomposition, owing to its excellent ability to cleave N–H bonds and promote N2 desorption [6–11]. However, its high cost and limited availability present significant barriers to large-scale deployment [12]. To address this, significant efforts have been made to identify alternative catalysts, particularly non-precious metals such as Fe, Co, and Ni. While these metals are more cost-effective, their catalytic performance is generally lower than Ru [13]. For example, studies using Density Functional Theory (DFT) on Fe (110), Co (111), and Ni (111) surfaces have shown that nitrogen desorption is the rate-determining step (RDS) for these metals, with adsorption energy following the order Fe > Co > Ni [13,14]. Similarly, investigations of precious metals, including Pd, Rh, and Pt, using DFT calculations revealed that the initial N–H bond cleavage is typically the RDS, particularly for Pd. Rh, however, exhibits superior catalytic activity compared to Pt and Pd, making it a promising alternative to Ru despite its lower efficiency [15]. In recent years, significant advancements have been achieved in developing bimetallic catalysts, alternative supports, and optimized metal structures to address the limitations of conventional catalytic systems. A primary focus has been on reducing the cost of Ru-based catalysts by incorporating non-precious metals in bimetallic combinations. This approach harnesses synergistic interactions between metals to enhance catalytic performance while minimizing material costs. For instance, Ni-Ru bimetallic catalysts supported on CeO2 have been extensively studied, revealing a catalytic hierarchy: Ru/CeO2 > NiRu/CeO2 > Ni/CeO2. These results highlight the essential role of bimetallic interactions in improving catalytic efficiency. Furthermore, these catalysts demonstrate excellent stability and resistance to deactivation under harsh reaction conditions, underscoring the robustness of bimetallic designs [16]. Similarly, Ru-Co bimetallic catalysts have shown notable promise for ammonia decomposition. Synergistic interactions between Ru and Co enhance catalytic performance, with Ru promoting hydrogen desorption and Co facilitating N–H bond activation [17]. Beyond Ru-based systems, other bimetallic catalysts, such as Pd-Cu and Co-Ni, have demonstrated significant potential. For example, Pd-Cu catalysts enhance NH3 dehydrogenation activity by altering the electronic structure and optimizing surface properties, outperforming monometallic Cu. Similarly, Co-Ni catalysts, such as Co9Ni1/SiO2, exhibit superior catalytic activity and stability compared to their monometallic counterparts. The reduced apparent activation energy observed in Co-Ni systems highlights the synergistic effects between the two metals, effectively lowering the energy barrier for ammonia decomposition and further demonstrating the advantages of bimetallic catalysts [18,19]. The catalytic performance of metal-based systems is significantly influenced by the choice of support material, which affects metal dispersion, electronic properties, and metal-support interactions, including strong metal-support interactions (SMSI) [7,20–24]. For instance, catalysts supported on reducible oxides such as TiO2 often exhibit SMSI effects that modify the electronic environment of active sites, altering NH3 activation and decomposition pathways. This has been observed in Ru/TiO2 systems, where SMSI enhances catalytic activity by improving hydrogen spillover and nitrogen desorption [25]. Similarly, Ru/CeO2 catalysts benefit from strong metal-support interactions, with the oxygen storage capacity of CeO2 facilitating reaction pathways [26]. These examples highlight the crucial role of support materials in optimizing catalytic efficiency and stability in NH3 decomposition. In other words, the significant influence of support interactions on catalytic performance makes it difficult to isolate the intrinsic activity of the active metal itself. Therefore, a systematic screening approach that eliminates support effects is necessary to identify intrinsically high-performance catalysts for NH3 decomposition. To address these challenges, this study first screens NH3 decomposition catalysts based on their intrinsic reactivity using DFT calculations, followed by experimental validation with reactor tests. By evaluating NH3 dissociation and N2 desorption energetics, we identify metals that balance both properties effectively. Since no monometallic catalyst outperforms Ru, we extend our approach to bimetallic systems to explore potential synergistic effects for cost-effective catalyst development. Our results highlight Ru, Rh, Ni, Ir, and Co as promising candidates, with RuNi emerging as a particularly effective alloy, offering a viable alternative for efficient and affordable hydrogen production. 2 Method 2.1 Computational detail Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were conducted using the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP), employing plane-wave basis sets and projector-augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials [27,28]. The Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was utilized, with plane-wave cutoff energies set to 600 eV for bulk calculations and 400 eV for surface studies [29]. For the slab models, the bottom two atomic layers were fixed while allowing the remaining atoms to relax until the forces converged to less than 0.03 eV/Å. To minimize interactions between periodic surfaces, a vacuum spacing of ∼ 20 Å was applied. The computational setup for slab models used a 2 × 2 unit cell and a Monkhorst–Pack k-point grid of 2 × 2 × 1. A computational screening of transition metals, including 21 species, was performed, focusing on their energetically most stable structures and surface facets (see Fig. 1 ). More specifically, for each metal, we selected 2 to 4 surfaces for screening based on literature reports, including the thermodynamically most stable facet and two additional low-index surfaces with relatively high stability. When such data were unavailable, surface energy calculations were used to identify the favorable facets. In total, 58 catalytic surfaces were examined. For further analysis, we focused on Ru, Co, Ir, Ni, and Rh metals. Specifically, the thermodynamically stable phases of hexagonal close-packed (hcp, P63/mmc) structures for Ru and Co, and face-centered cubic (fcc, Fm3‾m) structures for Ir, Ni, and Rh were examined. Based on the screening results, the active facets Ru(0001), Co(0001), Rh(100), Ir(100), and Ni(111) were selected for further investigation. Fig. S1 presents the slab models of Ru(0001), Co(0001), Ir(100), Ni(111), and Rh(100). The adsorption of reaction intermediates on the surfaces was simulated, representing an NHx coverage of approximately ∼ 6.25 % of the total surface metal atom density. Adsorption energy ( E ads ) was defined using Eq. (1): (1) E ads = E gas + E surf - E mol + s u r f # Here, E mol + s u r f is the energy of the molecule adsorbed on the surface, E surf is the energy of the bare surface, and E gas is the energy of the isolated gas-phase molecule. Note that this definition yields a positive adsorption energy for stable binding, which differs in sign from the more conventional negative-valued formulation. We adopted this convention because it provides a more intuitive measure of binding strength—larger Eads directly reflects stronger adsorption and higher desorption energy, consistent with experimental interpretation. In this study, the Gibbs free energy (G) of adsorbed species was computed using Eq. (2): (2) G A ∗ = E DFT + Z P E + U vib - T S vib # Here, EDFT represents the DFT-calculated energy, ZPE is the zero-point energy, Uvib corresponds to vibrational contributions to internal energy, and Svib is the vibrational entropy. For gas-phase molecules under ideal conditions, additional contributions from translational and rotational motions, along with the term RT, were included in the free energy calculations. 2.2 Experimental detail 2.2.1 Preparation of catalysts The M/SiO2 (M = Ru, Rh, Co, Ir, Fe, Ni, Cu, Zn, and W) catalysts were synthesized using the wet impregnation method. Metal precursors, including RuCl3∙xH2O, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, H2Cl6Ir∙xH2O and Rh(NO3)3∙xH2O (all obtained from Sigma-Aldrich), were dissolved in 250 mL distilled water to prepare the catalyst solutions. The metal loadings were calculated to achieve an equal molar amount of active metal (0.19 mmol/gcat), equivalent to 2 wt% Ru. Fumed SiO2 (Sigma-Aldrich) was added to the precursor solutions, and the mixtures were stirred for 12 h to ensure uniform dispersion. The resulting materials were dried at 120 °C for 4 h, followed by calcination at 550 °C for 6 h in a muffle furnace. The calcined powder samples were pelletized into 20–30 mesh for activity test in a fixed-bed reactor. 2.2.2 Catalysts activity test The catalytic activity of the prepared materials was evaluated using a tubular quartz reactor integrated with a temperature-programmed electric tubular furnace. The powdered catalyst, with a bed volume of 0.2 cm3, was employed to ensure uniform reaction conditions for comparative activity assessment. The performance tests were conducted at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 21,000 h−1. Prior to testing, the catalysts were pretreated at 500 °C for 40 min under a reducing atmosphere of 20 % H2/N2. Afterward, the reactor was cooled to 200 °C while maintaining the same gas flow. Steady-state activity measurements were performed across a temperature range of 200 to 450 °C in 50 °C increments, with a heating rate of 5 °C/min followed by a 20-minute holding period at each interval. The experiments were conducted under atmospheric pressure using a feed gas composed solely of NH3 at a 70 cm3/min flow rate. A mass spectrometer (MS, REALTEK) was employed to quantify the change in NH3 concentration during the reactor testing. To compare the intrinsic catalytic activity across different active metals, all kinetic evaluations were performed under identical temperature conditions in the range of 275 °C to 315 °C. Within this window, the reaction was maintained under steady-state conditions, and NH3 conversion remained in a regime suitable for kinetic interpretation. The support was fixed as SiO2, and only the identity of the active metal was varied. To enable a consistent comparison, the number of surface-active metal sites was quantified by CO chemisorption, and the corresponding dispersion values were used to normalize TOF. This methodology allows a reliable evaluation of intrinsic kinetics across the metal species under uniform experimental conditions. The TOF was calculated using Eq. (3), which normalizes the amount of NH3 converted (in moles) by the number of exposed active metal sites and the reaction time (in seconds). The apparent activation energy (Ea) was then determined from the linearized form of the Arrhenius equation, as shown in Eq. (4): (3) T O F o f NH 3 = Converted NH 3 a m o u n t m o l D activemetal ∙ A c t i v e m e t a l c o n t e n t ( m o l ) ∙ s e c (4) A p p a r e n t a c t i v a t i o n e n e r g y E a = R T ∙ ln A - ln T O F 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Computational screening In ammonia decomposition, the initial cleavage of N–H bonds and the desorption of N2 are recognized as key elementary steps [13,30–32]. For precious metals such as Ru, Rh, Ir, Pt, and Pd, the cleavage of N–H bonds is generally the rate-determining step, with the dissociation energy (Ediss) described as Ediss = ENH2* + 0.5E N2*(g) − ENH3*. In contrast, for non-precious metals such as Fe, Co, and Ni, the primary rate-determining step is typically the desorption of N2 [13]. High-performance ammonia decomposition requires minimizing the dissociation energy from NH3 to NH2 to promote efficient decomposition while also ensuring a low adsorption energy for N2 to facilitate desorption and prevent blockage of catalytic active sites. To address these requirements, this study aimed to identify metals that satisfy both criteria. Highly active Ru was chosen as the reference, with screening thresholds set to Ediss,NH3 < 57.7 kJ/mol and Ead,N2 < 89.9 kJ/mol. Although the actual dissociation energy for Ru is 47.7 kJ/mol, a 10 kJ/mol margin was applied to the cutoff to allow for a broader selection window, as this value is already sufficiently low to ensure activity. In contrast, no such margin was applied to Ead,N2, since 89.9 kJ/mol already represents relatively strong nitrogen adsorption; further relaxation could risk including catalysts prone to site poisoning. Fig. 2 a presents the screening results based on these thresholds. Metals that satisfy Ediss,NH3 < 57.7 kJ/mol include W, Mo, Re, Cr, Tc, V, Mn, Co, Ti, Rh, Zn, Os, Ni, Ru, Ir, and Fe, while those meeting Ead,N2 < 89.9 kJ/mol include Ru, Mn, Rh, Ni, Au, Cu, Ag, Zn, Pt, Pd, Ir, Tc, Os, Re, and Co. Metals that meet both criteria are Ru, Mn, Rh, Ni, Zn, Ir, Tc, Os, Re, and Co. Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC) analysis was performed to examine the relationships between electronic properties, dissociation energies, and N2 adsorption behavior shown in Fig. 2b. The PCC analysis revealed a strong inverse correlation between NH3 dissociation energy (Ediss,NH3) and N2 adsorption energy (Ead,N2), highlighting a tradeoff between these two properties. This relationship suggests a volcano-plot-like feature, where improving one property often compromises the other. Catalysts with lower Ead,N2 (weaker N2 adsorption) promote desorption and prevent active site blockage but may exhibit higher Ediss,NH3, reducing NH3 dissociation efficiency. Conversely, catalysts with lower Ediss,NH3 (enhanced NH3 cleavage) tend to stabilize N2 adsorption, potentially hindering desorption and catalytic turnover. Striking a balance between these two properties is crucial for efficient catalysis. The position of the d-band center relative to the Fermi level, as represented by d center- (d band center relative to below fermi level) and d center+ (d band center relative to above fermi level), significantly impacts catalytic performance. A decrease in the d center+ and an increase in the d center- indicate that the overall d-band center is closer to the Fermi level, which enhances electron transfer between the metallic surface to adsorbates. This facilitates the stabilization of intermediates, such as NH2, thereby lowering Ediss,NH3 (Ediss,NH3 = ENH3* − ENH2*). A similar correlation is observed for N2 adsorption energy (Ead,N2), where N2 binding becomes stronger as the d-band center moves closer to the Fermi level shown in Fig. 2b. In particular, the stronger binding energy primarily arises from donation (electron transfer from N2 to metallic surface) and back donation (electron transfer from metallic surface to N2) interactions. Ead,N2 decreases as the energy gaps between d center+ and HOMO (d center+ − HOMO), and d- center and LUMO (d center- − LUMO) widen, as a larger gap requires higher energy for electron transfer [33]. This suggests that a d-band center closer to the Fermi level facilitates donation and back donation interactions between N2 and the metallic surface, thereby enhancing N2 adsorption. Fractional filling (ff) also plays a key role. A decreased fractional filling (ff) strengthens electron transfer from the adsorbates to metal surface (donation interaction), driving the stabilization of NH2 adsorption. Since Ediss,NH3 is strongly correlated with NH2 adsorption stability, metals with low ff are better at stabilizing NH2 by electron transfer from NH2 to metal (donation interactions), making NH3 dissociation more favorable. The relationship between Ediss,NH3, Ead,N2, the d-band center, and fractional filling (ff) underscores the tradeoff between NH3 dissociation and N2 desorption revealed by PCC analysis. Catalysts with lower Ediss,NH3 promote NH3 cleavage but risk stronger N2 adsorption, while lower Ead,N2 facilitates desorption but may hinder NH3 dissociation. Metals with a d-band center near the Fermi level and optimized ff achieve a balance, stabilizing NH2 intermediates and maintaining manageable Ead,N2. The screened metals, including Ru, Mn, Rh, Ni, Zn, Ir, Tc, Os, Re, and Co, demonstrate favorable d-band characteristics and fractional filling values, positioning them near the apex of the volcano plot. These properties optimize NH3 dissociation and N2 desorption, ensuring efficient catalytic activity for ammonia decomposition. The observed inverse correlation between NH3 activation and N2 desorption energies thus provides a mechanistic insight that can be harnessed to design next-generation catalysts. In particular, identifying material combinations that reconcile this trade-off—such as through alloying or surface modification—could enable the discovery of effective catalytic systems beyond monometallic surfaces. Although the proposed metals (Ru, Mn, Rh, Ni, Zn, Ir, Tc, Os, Re, and Co) initially met the energetic screening criteria, additional refinement was necessary to account for practical considerations, including economic feasibility, environmental impact, and chemical stability. As a result, Mn, Zn, Tc, Os, and Re were excluded from further analysis due to their inherent limitations. Manganese, although theoretically promising due to its ability to exist in multiple oxidation states (Mn0, Mn2+, Mn4+), which could support catalytic activity through redox flexibility, was excluded. Its high susceptibility to oxidation and phase changes under the high-temperature conditions required for ammonia decomposition leads to the deactivation of active sites, significantly reducing its durability and effectiveness as a catalyst [34]. Zinc was excluded as a potential catalyst due to its low boiling point and high volatility, which compromise its stability under the high-temperature conditions required for ammonia decomposition [35]. Technetium, while possessing some theoretical potential, was excluded due to its radioactive nature and limited availability, as it is primarily derived as a byproduct of nuclear fission. These factors make technetium impractical and unsafe for industrial applications [36]. Osmium, despite its capability for high catalytic activity, was excluded due to its extreme scarcity, high cost, and the toxicity of its compounds, particularly osmium tetroxide (OsO4) [37]. Furthermore, the lack of oxidative stability of osmium further limits its viability under catalytic conditions. Rhenium, although thermally and oxidatively stable, was excluded primarily due to its extreme rarity and the associated high cost, which make it impractical for large-scale catalytic applications [38]. Its limited availability poses significant economic and logistical challenges, further reducing its feasibility for widespread use. After these exclusions, Ru, Rh, Ni, Ir, and Co were identified as the most promising candidates for further investigation. 3.2 Thermodynamic analysis for NH3 decomposition To further validate the screening data, we evaluated the Gibbs free energy for NH3 decomposition on the proposed surfaces (Ru(0001), Rh(100), Ir(100), Ni(111) and Co(0001)) shown in Fig. 3 , using the favored configurations of reaction intermediates presented in Figs. S2 and S3. The thermodynamic profiles reveal that Ru, Rh, Ni, and Ir exhibit favorable catalytic properties, whereas Co faces distinct challenges due to strong nitrogen adsorption, which hinders its efficiency. Ru, Rh, and Ni share smooth and balanced energy trends, exhibiting moderate thermodynamic barriers for NH3 dissociation. The NH3 → NH2 step requires ΔG = 19.4 kJ/mol for Ru, 14.3 kJ/mol for Rh, and 26.1 kJ/mol for Ni, indicating that the first N–H bond cleavage is thermodynamically accessible for all three metals. In the NH2 → NH step, Ru and Ni exhibit strongly exergonic trends (ΔG = − 33.3 kJ/mol and − 22.6 kJ/mol, respectively), while Rh shows a small uphill barrier (ΔG = 5.3 kJ/mol), ensuring smooth progression of this step. However, the NH → N step introduces greater variability, where Ru maintains a moderate uphill trend (ΔG = 13.1 kJ/mol), while Rh and Ni encounter higher barriers (ΔG = 36.1 kJ/mol and 43.5 kJ/mol, respectively). Despite these differences, the overall profiles of Ru, Rh, and Ni remain favorable. The desorption of nitrogen further underscores the catalytic efficiency of Ru, Rh, and Ni, with all three metals exhibiting pathways that enable effective N2 release. Ru initially stabilizes N∗ at its most stable site (N∗(1st)), but diffusion to N∗(2nd) weakens the binding (ΔG = 24.4 kJ/mol), facilitating desorption. Ni follows a similar trend, while Rh achieves desorption directly from N∗(1st) with a moderate barrier (ΔG = 35.4 kJ/mol). These moderate barriers indicate that nitrogen desorption is not a significant hindrance for Ru, Rh, and Ni, further reinforcing their effectiveness in NH3 decomposition. Ir also demonstrates promising catalytic performance. It exhibits highly favorable NH3 adsorption (ΔG = − 62.8 kJ/mol) and a small thermodynamic barrier for NH3 → NH2 (ΔG = 4.7 kJ/mol), reflecting efficient NH3 cleavage. However, the NH2 → NH step presents an uphill barrier (ΔG = 51.9 kJ/mol), and the NH → N step remains challenging (ΔG = 45.6 kJ/mol). Nevertheless, Ir achieves efficient nitrogen desorption directly from the most stable adsorption site (N∗(1st)) without requiring diffusion to N∗(2nd), distinguishing it from Ru and Ni. Its direct desorption pathway remains efficient, further supporting its catalytic viability despite the challenges in intermediate steps. In contrast, Co exhibits distinct thermodynamic challenges, particularly in the later stages of NH3 decomposition. The NH3 → NH2 step requires the lowest energy input among the metals (ΔG = 9.0 kJ/mol), and the NH2 → NH step is strongly exergonic (ΔG = − 44.9 kJ/mol), suggesting efficient early-stage dehydrogenation. However, the NH → N step introduces a moderate barrier (ΔG = 25.4 kJ/mol), and nitrogen desorption is significantly hindered by strong binding at both N∗(1st) (ΔG = 95.2 kJ/mol) and N∗(2nd) (ΔG = 72.5 kJ/mol). This strong adsorption limits active site regeneration and ultimately reduces the catalytic turnover of Co, making it less effective than Ru, Rh, Ni, and Ir. The thermodynamic profiles indicate that Ru, Rh, Ni, and Ir are effective catalysts for NH3 decomposition, as they exhibit smooth energy trends and efficient nitrogen desorption. Co, however, faces limitations due to strong nitrogen adsorption, which hinders its catalytic efficiency despite its favorable early-stage performance. The similarities among Ru, Rh, Ni, and Ir make it difficult to establish a definitive reactivity ranking, emphasizing the need for further experimental and kinetic studies to differentiate their relative performance. 3.3 Reactivity evaluation of other facets To address the limitations of relying solely on the chosen facets selected from the initial screening for catalytic reactivity predictions, we investigated the Ediss,NH3 and Ead,N2 values of other potentially stable facets, as summarized in the statistical data provided in Table 1 . These metrics are critical for predicting NH3 decomposition kinetics, as lower energy values generally correspond to better catalytic performance. Importantly, the results indicate that none of the studied metals exhibit erratic behavior across different facets, suggesting that surface variation does not introduce major limitations in their catalytic properties. The computational results show that Ru, Rh, Ni, and Ir maintain stable Ediss,NH3 and Ead,N2 values across multiple facets, indicating consistent catalytic behavior. For Ru, the average Ediss,NH3 and Ead,N2 are 36.8 kJ/mol and 64.3 kJ/mol, respectively, with standard deviations of 10.2 kJ/mol and 13.7kJ/mol. Ni shows similar trends, with average values of 37.3 kJ/mol for Ediss,NH3 and 63.3 kJ/mol for Ead,N2, with standard deviations of 16.1 kJ/mol and 15.3 kJ/mol. Rh and Ir also exhibit stable values, though with slightly higher variations. Rh has average Ediss,NH3 and Ead,N2 values of 49.4 kJ/mol and 64.6 kJ/mol, with standard deviations of 12.2 kJ/mol and 15.0 kJ/mol. Ir exhibits slightly greater variation, with average Ediss,NH3 and Ead,N2 values of 51.6 kJ/mol and 63.6 kJ/mol, and standard deviations of 30.0 kJ/mol and 25.3 kJ/mol. These results indicate that none of these metals show unexpected deviations across different facets, reinforcing the reliability of their catalytic properties. Co also follows a consistent trend across its surfaces but shows distinct characteristics compared to the other metals. Co exhibits the lowest average Ediss,NH3 at 20.4 kJ/mol, while its Ead,N2 is higher at 72.5 kJ/mol, with standard deviations of 17.6 kJ/mol and 15.2 kJ/mol. The strong N* binding observed across different Co facets remains a notable feature, leading to reduced active site availability. Free energy analysis further confirms this, showing strong nitrogen adsorption with ΔG = 95.2 kJ/mol at N*(1st) and 72.5 kJ/mol at N*(2nd), which limits nitrogen desorption and reduces catalytic turnover. Although Co does not exhibit erratic variations across surfaces, its inherently strong nitrogen adsorption restricts its overall efficiency in NH3 decomposition. Overall, the computational results confirm that Ru, Rh, Ni, and Ir maintain stable catalytic behavior across different facets, without unexpected fluctuations that could negatively impact performance. Co also follows a consistent trend, though its strong nitrogen adsorption differentiates it from the other metals. The absence of erratic behavior across all studied surfaces suggests that these metals provide reliable catalytic properties for NH3 decomposition, reinforcing their suitability for further investigation. 3.4 Experimental verification of catalytic NH3 decomposition To experimentally validate the computational predictions regarding supported metal catalysts, reactor tests were conducted on M/SiO2 catalysts (M = Ru, Rh, Ir, Ni, or Co). SiO2 was chosen as a support due to its inert nature, minimizing metal-support interactions. The metal content was maintained at 0.197 mmol/g∙catalyst to ensure a fair comparison of intrinsic catalytic activity. As shown in Table S1, the dispersion of each metal remained close to 12 %, confirming that NH3 decomposition activity was measured under well-normalized conditions. As shown in Fig. 4 a, Ru exhibited the highest NH3 conversion across all tested temperatures. At 450 °C, the catalytic performance followed the trend: Ru (91.5 %) > Rh (54.1 %) > Ir (37.8 %) > Ni (35.4 %) > Co (31.6 %), demonstrating the superior activity of Ru. To confirm the reliability of these catalytic activities, each experiment was performed twice under identical conditions. The corresponding average NH3 conversions and standard deviations at each temperature are summarized in Table S1, verifying the reproducibility and consistency of the activity measurements. Notably, Ni exhibited similar NH3 dissociation and N2 desorption energies to Ru in computational screening (Table 1), yet its experimental performance was significantly lower. This suggests that additional factors, such as kinetics, surface stability, or reaction intermediates, may influence catalytic efficiency beyond the intrinsic adsorption energetics captured in DFT calculations. To further examine the correlation between computational and experimental findings, turnover frequency (TOF, s−1) and apparent activation energy (Ea, kJ/mol) were evaluated, as shown in Figs. 4b and S4. At 295 °C, TOF followed the order Ru (3.84 s−1) > Rh (1.78 s−1) > Ir (1.00 s−1) > Ni (0.41 s−1) > Co (0.38 s−1), closely aligning with activation energy trends: Ru (49.9 kJ/mol) < Rh (55.1 kJ/mol) < Ir (56.5 kJ/mol) < Ni (58.7 kJ/mol) < Co (74.6 kJ/mol). The low activation energy of Ru is consistent with its favorable NH3 dissociation and N2 desorption energies from DFT calculations, reaffirming that Ru is the most efficient catalyst for NH3 decomposition by ensuring both efficient NH3 activation and rapid N2 removal from active sites. In addition, the free energy profile of Ru further explains its superior activity. The NH3 → NH2 and NH2 → NH steps exhibit low energy barriers, while the NH → N transition is only moderately uphill. Furthermore, nitrogen desorption is thermodynamically accessible, preventing active site poisoning and ensuring sustained catalytic turnover. These characteristics enable Ru to maintain high catalytic efficiency across a range of reaction conditions. While Ni exhibited comparable adsorption energetics in computational screening, its higher activation energy and lower TOF indicate possible kinetic limitations or secondary interactions that hinder its experimental performance. In contrast, the high activation energy of Co (74.6 kJ/mol) and low TOF (0.38 s−1) confirm its relatively poor catalytic efficiency, which aligns with computational predictions indicating strong nitrogen adsorption as a key limiting factor. The excessive binding of N2 on Co surfaces likely blocks active sites and slows catalytic turnover, making it significantly less effective than Ru and other metals. These findings confirm that Ru is the most effective catalyst, with both computational and experimental results demonstrating its superior intrinsic reactivity. Although Ni exhibited comparable adsorption energetics in DFT calculations, its lower experimental performance suggests the presence of kinetic limitations or secondary interactions not captured in computational screening. In contrast, the results for Ru, Rh, Ir, and Co align well with computational predictions, indicating that adsorption energetics and free energy profiles provide a reliable basis for catalyst screening. This overall agreement underscores the effectiveness of DFT-based screening while also highlighting the importance of experimental validation to fully capture real-world catalytic behavior. 3.5 Metals alloy screening of NH3 decomposition By employing the proposed dual approach—evaluating ΔE (Ediss,NH3 and Ead,N2) alongside free energy profiles—we performed computational screening to identify high-performance catalysts for NH3 decomposition. As an initial step, alloy combinations were explored based on single-metal catalysts identified in prior screening, including Ru, Co, Ni, Rh, and Ir. Binary alloys of these metals were systematically examined, encompassing all possible combinations: RuCo, RuNi, RuRh, RuIr, CoNi, CoRh, CoIr, NiRh, NiIr, and RhIr. Surface stability calculations were conducted for multiple crystallographic orientations, including (001), (010), (011), (100), (101), (110), and (111). From these calculations, 2–4 stable surfaces were identified for each bimetallic system, resulting in a total of 26 systems. Further details on the development of bimetallic systems are provided in the SI4. Initial screening was conducted based on Ediss,NH3 (57.7 kJ/mol) and Ead,N2 (89.9 kJ/mol) thresholds for bimetallic systems, as shown in Fig. 5 . The results revealed that 18 systems satisfied the Ediss,NH3 criterion, while 25 systems met the Ead,N2 criterion, with most bimetallic systems exhibiting high resistance to N* poisoning due to weak nitrogen adsorption. Among these, 17 systems met both criteria, including CoNi(001)–Co, CoNi(001)-Ni, CoRh(001)–Co, CoRu(001)–Co, CoRu(001)-Ru, CoRu(011), IrCo(010), IrNi(001)-Ni, IrRh(100), IrRu(001)-Ru, RhNi(010), RhNi(011), RuNi(011), RuNi(100), RuRh(001)-Rh, RuRh(001)-Ru, and RuRh(011) where −M indicates that the top surface is covered by the M metal species. Further screening involved evaluating the Gibbs free energy profiles for NH3 decomposition on the selected surfaces. Thermodynamically smooth profiles were identified as indicators of high reactivity, with Ru and Ni serving as benchmarks due to their demonstrated high activity and distinct yet favorable free energy profiles (see Fig. 3). Detailed ΔG data for the selected systems and the screening process are provided in section S6 in SI. From this analysis, RuNi(011) emerged as the only surface with a sufficiently smooth free energy profile to meet the criteria for high catalytic performance. To further confirm the reactivity of the RuNi catalyst, we additionally evaluated the free energy profiles of other stable RuNi facets (see Fig. 6 ). The results indicate that most RuNi surfaces exhibit smooth profiles, with behavior similar to that observed for pure Ru and Ni surfaces. Notably, the (101) surface displayed a distinct behavior compared to other facets, showing a smooth increase in ΔG with moderately high free energy differences for each step. The above results from dual approach suggest that RuNi bimetallic alloy catalyst, showing low Δ E (Ediss,NH3 and Ead,N2) and smooth Δ G profile, would exhibit catalytic performance comparable to or exceeding that of pure Ru catalysts, offering a promising alternative for efficient NH3 decomposition. Several experimental studies have reported that Ru-Ni bimetallic catalysts exhibit high catalytic activity due to the synergistic interaction between Ru and Ni. However, these studies do not focus solely on intrinsic reactivity, and the investigated systems are not true bimetallic alloys, as Ru and Ni do not form a homogeneous alloy but rather exist as separate phases or physical mixtures, differing from our proposed Ni/Ru alloy [16,39,40]. To the best of our knowledge, studies on Ru/Ni bimetallic alloy catalysts for NH3 decomposition are highly limited. Notably, one study proposed that Ni-Ru alloys exhibit a lower activation energy than Ru-based catalysts, including Ru, Ru-Co, and Ru-Cu bimetallic systems. Furthermore, they outperform other noble metal monometallic catalysts, such as Pd and Rh, in terms of activation energy [41]. However, the bimetallic systems in the discussed literature are not true alloy systems, as they exhibit metal mixing but deviate from an ideal alloy, which would have a perfectly homogeneous atomic distribution and consistent electronic properties across the structure. Therefore, achieving precise synthesis and structural control of Ru-Ni alloys could unlock their full potential, paving the way for the development of highly efficient and durable catalysts for ammonia decomposition. 4 Conclusion This study demonstrates that while Ru remains the benchmark catalyst for NH3 decomposition, bimetallic alloys offer a promising route to enhance catalytic efficiency and reduce noble metal dependence. Computational screening and free energy analysis were used to identify promising catalysts, and the resulting dataset was analyzed using Pearson correlation coefficient analysis to uncover key electronic descriptors governing catalytic activity. The PCC results revealed a volcano-type correlation between NH3 dissociation energy (Ediss,NH3) and N2 adsorption energy (Ead,N2), highlighting the tradeoff between NH3 activation and N2 desorption. Ru was positioned near the peak of this trend, confirming its superior catalytic performance among mono metals. This mechanistic insight offers a rational design guideline for developing next-generation catalysts. In particular, alloying or surface modification strategies that balance this trade-off could lead to improved catalytic performance beyond monometallic systems. Experimental validation of monometallic catalysts confirmed the computational predictions, reinforcing the reliability of this approach. Extending this validated strategy to bimetallic systems, Ru-Ni alloys, particularly RuNi(011), emerged as a promising candidate with balanced adsorption energetics and favorable free energy profiles. These findings underscore the effectiveness of data-guided computational screening in identifying high-performance catalysts. Future research should focus on synthesizing and structurally optimizing Ru-Ni alloys to experimentally verify their predicted activity. The development of well-designed bimetallic catalysts could further enhance NH3 decomposition efficiency, supporting scalable hydrogen production technologies. coredata.dc:description: Ammonia decomposition is a promising route for CO2-free hydrogen production, but the development of efficient and cost-effective catalysts remains a challenge. Here, we employed a dual approach combining computational screening and free energy analysis to identify optimal catalysts, which were then validated experimentally. Pearson correlation coefficient analysis revealed a volcano-type relationship between NH3 dissociation energy (Ediss,NH3) and N2 adsorption energy (Ead,N2), highlighting Ru as the most effective monometallic catalyst. Reactor tests using supported Ru, Rh, Ir, Ni, and Co catalysts confirmed these predictions, with Ru exhibiting the highest NH3 conversion and a strong correlation between turnover frequency, activation energy (Ea), and electronic descriptors. Using this validated approach, we extended our analysis to bimetallic systems, identifying Ru-Ni alloys, as a promising alternative with balanced NH3 activation and N2 desorption. These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of combining computational and experimental methods to design high-performance NH3 decomposition catalysts. Further refinement of Ru-Ni alloy synthesis and structural control could enhance catalytic activity, supporting scalable hydrogen production.
